instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message:
Hi ive got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board which had liquid damage, no green light so so replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> and now have charger light but no fan spin, check power rails 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = present
PPBUS S5 HS COMPUTING = present
PPBUS S5 HS OTHER5V = present
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> = present
PP3V42 G3H = present
PPVRTC G3H = present
PP5V S5 = present
PP5V S4 = missing so ive measured at <CHIP>U8060</CHIP> where <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> should be and <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> isnt present at pin 2 but when i go looking for that i cant find where it is made or comes from, am i missing the obvious ??? , i must admit i do get a bit confused as to what power rails are needed for the board to be turning on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message:
Always post voltages, not only if it is present or not....

<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> ---><RESISTOR>R8115</RESISTOR> and so on...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message: Sorry about the voltages would have made more sense, yes should have said, i see it comes from PM SLP S5 L (i knew what i meant :-) ,guess id had a long day) but i cant see where PM SLP S5 L comes from, thats the only place on the schematic for it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message: Where was the liquid damage? Is the board power cycling, check for short pulses on <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> preferably with a scope as with a multimeter will be hard/impossible to see cause pulses are very short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message: Hi Duke all the liquid damage was around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3090</CHIP> but also looks like the ssd has some too, im afraid i dont have a scope , did try with the meter but couldnt detect anything , would be willing to order a scope if you think it would make my life easier :-)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing PP5V S4
threads.message: This could be anything really. Check <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> for corrosion and possibly crap under the SMC. Did you check all other rails for short to GND?
